guide.conclusion: This project first appeared in MAKE Volume 26, page 80.

flags.title: Weekend Project
flags.text: This project is part of RadioShack's The Great Create.

guide.introduction:
The Luna Mod is an easy and fun instrument that will have you making great-sounding loops in no time. Rather than sampling input like a traditional loop station, the Luna Mod synthesizes its own sounds, and you play it using two knobs and one button.

I based the Luna Mod on the Wicks Looper, which I sell on Etsy, but it’s designed to be even simpler to build and play, without any complicated functions that would never get used. One knob controls the sound generated, the other controls the tempo of the loop, and the button writes the current sound into the ongoing loop. The variety of sounds you can get from these three controls is amazing.

You don’t need any special or expensive tools to build the Luna Mod, and it was designed for hackability. Its handy, built-in programming port lets you easily upload new firmware to the microcontroller chip, in order to change the sounds the instrument produces and which variables are tied to which controls.

Check out more Weekend Projects.
guide.introduction_rendered:
The Luna Mod is an easy and fun instrument that will have you making great-sounding loops in no time. Rather than sampling input like a traditional loop station, the Luna Mod synthesizes its own sounds, and you play it using two knobs and one button.

I based the Luna Mod on the Wicks Looper, which I sell on Etsy, but it’s designed to be even simpler to build and play, without any complicated functions that would never get used. One knob controls the sound generated, the other controls the tempo of the loop, and the button writes the current sound into the ongoing loop. The variety of sounds you can get from these three controls is amazing.

You don’t need any special or expensive tools to build the Luna Mod, and it was designed for hackability. Its handy, built-in programming port lets you easily upload new firmware to the microcontroller chip, in order to change the sounds the instrument produces and which variables are tied to which controls.

Check out more Weekend Projects.

Relevant parts
  • Stripboard
  • Microprocessor
  • Potentiometer, linear, vertical PCB mount
  • LED, 5mm, blue
  • Voltage regulator, 5V, 7805
  • Resistor, 500-piece assorment, 1/4 Watt
  • Switch, micro-mini toggle
  • IC socket, 8 pin
  • Audio jack, Stereo inline, 1/8"
  • Switch, momentary pushbutton
  • Audio jack, mono, ¼" panel-mount
  • Battery, 9V
  • Battery clip 9V
  • Picaxe programming cable
  • LED holders
  • Knob, to fit a ¼" (6.35mm) shaft
  • Wood boards
  • Box hinges
  • Capacitor ceramic 0.01µF
  • Capacitor, ceramic, 0.1µF
  • Hookup wire, 22 AWG stranded
  • Hookup wire, 22 AWG
Tools
  • Allen wrench
  • Beeswax
  • Carpenter's square
  • Chisel
  • Computer
  • Drill
  • Drill bits
  • Glue
  • Hacksaw
  • Handsaw
  • Headphones
  • Hot glue gun
  • Luna Mod BASIC code
  • PC computer
  • Pencil
  • Pliers
  • Ruler
  • Sandpaper
  • Sash clamp
  • Schematic diagram
  • Screwdriver
  • Solder, lead-free
  • Soldering Iron, 15 Watt
  • Wire cutter and stripper
  • Wood clamps

parts.notes: can be cut from a larger board, such as 3"x3.5" #V2018-ND from Digi-Key (digikey.com),or the 2"x5" 1000L Phenolic from Veroboard (veroboard.com)

parts.text: Knob, to fit a ¼" (6.35mm) shaft

parts.notes: You'll cut 7 small pieces; the exact dimensions in standard and metric measurements are given in Step 2. I used pine; you can use 2" pine craft boards, such as #50226 and #50234 from Lowe's (lowes.com).
available packed together from most hardware stores

lines.text: Take a 26x16-hole piece of stripboard (use a sharp hacksaw as necessary to cut to size, then sand the edges smooth). The copper strips should run the long way.
lines.text_raw: Take a 26x16-hole piece of stripboard (use a sharp hacksaw as necessary to cut to size, then sand the edges smooth). The copper strips should run the long way.

lines.text: To identify holes on the board for placing components, I use grid references of the form (x,y), where (1,1) is the top left hole of the non-solder pad side, and the board’s long edge and copper strips run along the x-axis.
lines.text_raw: To identify holes on the board for placing components, I use grid references of the form (x,y), where (1,1) is the top left hole of the non-solder pad side, and the board’s long edge and copper strips run along the x-axis.

lines.text: On the shorter jumpers you can remove all the insulation on the wires.
lines.text_raw: On the shorter jumpers you can remove all the insulation on the wires.

lines.text: Remember to count the x-coordinate from right to left when the board’s copper side is facing you.
lines.text_raw: Remember to count the x-coordinate from right to left when the board’s copper side is facing you.

lines.text: Solder the resistors onto the stripboard: 1kΩ (18,12 to 18,16) and (25,12 to 25,16); 10kΩ (2,12 to 2,16), (9,7 to 9,14), (10,3 to 10,13), and (21,3 to 21,7); and 22kΩ (3,12 to 7,12).
lines.text_raw: Solder the resistors onto the stripboard: 1kΩ (18,12 to 18,16) and (25,12 to 25,16); 10kΩ (2,12 to 2,16), (9,7 to 9,14), (10,3 to 10,13), and (21,3 to 21,7); and 22kΩ (3,12 to 7,12).

lines.text: Solder in the 8-pin IC socket with Pin 1 at (12,11) and Pin 8 at (15,11).
lines.text_raw: Solder in the 8-pin IC socket with Pin 1 at (12,11) and Pin 8 at (15,11).

lines.text: Solder in the 2 caps: 10nF (23,12 to 23,14) and 100nF (20,14 to 20,16).
lines.text_raw: Solder in the 2 caps: 10nF (23,12 to 23,14) and 100nF (20,14 to 20,16).

lines.text: Solder in the voltage regulator, Pin 1 to (3,5) and Pin 3 to (3,3).
lines.text_raw: Solder in the voltage regulator, Pin 1 to (3,5) and Pin 3 to (3,3).

lines.text: Trim the LED leads to ½" (14mm) to keep them long enough to poke up through the panel, but keep track of which legs are positive (anode, with the longer leg) and which are negative (cathode, shorter and marked by a flat part in the plastic).
lines.text_raw: Trim the LED leads to ½" (14mm) to keep them long enough to poke up through the panel, but keep track of which legs are positive (anode, with the longer leg) and which are negative (cathode, shorter and marked by a flat part in the plastic).

lines.text: Solder one LED with its (+) leg at (9,3) and (–) leg at (9,4), and the other with (+) at (18,3) and (–) at (18,4).
lines.text_raw: Solder one LED with its (+) leg at (9,3) and (–) leg at (9,4), and the other with (+) at (18,3) and (–) at (18,4).

lines.text: The on/off toggle switch legs are too wide to fit directly into the PCB holes, so use a 1/16" drill bit to extend the holes into small slots at (14,1), (14,2), and (14,3).
lines.text_raw: The on/off toggle switch legs are too wide to fit directly into the PCB holes, so use a 1/16" drill bit to extend the holes into small slots at (14,1), (14,2), and (14,3).

lines.text: Fit and solder the switch into place.
lines.text_raw: Fit and solder the switch into place.

lines.text: For the potentiometers, use the 5/16" bit to enlarge the holes at (1,6), (1,10), (26,6), and (26,10). Locate Pin 1 on each of the pots; it’s the rightmost pin as you face the pins with the pot shaft pointing up.
lines.text_raw: For the potentiometers, use the 5/16" bit to enlarge the holes at (1,6), (1,10), (26,6), and (26,10). Locate Pin 1 on each of the pots; it’s the rightmost pin as you face the pins with the pot shaft pointing up.

lines.text: Fit the pots’ mounting tabs into the enlarged holes with Pin 1 of one at (4,9) and Pin 1 of the other at (23,7). Solder into place.
lines.text_raw: Fit the pots’ mounting tabs into the enlarged holes with Pin 1 of one at (4,9) and Pin 1 of the other at (23,7). Solder into place.

lines.text: For the programming socket, cut 3 wires, ideally of different colors, about 3½" (or 9cm) long. Solder one end of each to (1,11), (1,12), and (1,13).
lines.text_raw: For the programming socket, cut 3 wires, ideally of different colors, about 3½" (or 9cm) long. Solder one end of each to (1,11), (1,12), and (1,13).

lines.text: Remove the 1/8" stereo jack cover, slip it over the 3 wires, and solder the wires to the jack’s contacts for the plug’s sleeve (inner), ring (middle), and tip (end), respectively. Replace the cover.
lines.text_raw: Remove the 1/8" stereo jack cover, slip it over the 3 wires, and solder the wires to the jack’s contacts for the plug’s sleeve (inner), ring (middle), and tip (end), respectively. Replace the cover.

steps.title: Wiring the pushbutton and audio jack

lines.text: Solder 2 wire leads for the pushbutton about 7" (or 18cm) long at locations (1,14) and (1,15).
lines.text_raw: Solder 2 wire leads for the pushbutton about 7" (or 18cm) long at locations (1,14) and (1,15).

lines.text: You’ll solder the pushbutton to these 2 loose wires after fitting it into the front of the panel.
lines.text_raw: You’ll solder the pushbutton to these 2 loose wires after fitting it into the front of the panel.

lines.text: Solder 2 wires about 7" (or 18cm) long to the PCB at (26,12) and (26,14). Solder the other ends to the panel-mount mono audio jack’s tip (signal) and sleeve (ground) contacts, respectively.
lines.text_raw: Solder 2 wires about 7" (or 18cm) long to the PCB at (26,12) and (26,14). Solder the other ends to the panel-mount mono audio jack’s tip (signal) and sleeve (ground) contacts, respectively.

lines.text: Solder the 9-volt battery clip to the board, red (+) to (1,2) and black (–) to (1,4).
lines.text_raw: Solder the 9-volt battery clip to the board, red (+) to (1,2) and black (–) to (1,4).

lines.text: Plug the Picaxe 08M into the IC socket with pin 1 at upper left, nearer the LEDs.
lines.text_raw: Plug the Picaxe 08M into the IC socket with pin 1 at upper left, nearer the LEDs.

lines.text: The circuit board is now  finished and ready to fit into the control panel.
lines.text_raw: The circuit board is now  finished and ready to fit into the control panel.

lines.text: Using 3/8" board, cut two 5½"×1 5/8" side pieces and two 2½"×1 5/8" end pieces. (Using 8mm boards, cut pieces 140mm×40mm and 65mm×40mm.)
lines.text_raw: Using 3/8" board, cut two 5½"×1 5/8" side pieces and two 2½"×1 5/8" end pieces. (Using 8mm boards, cut pieces 140mm×40mm and 65mm×40mm.)

lines.text: For the base, cut a piece 5 7/8"×3 5/8" (or for 8mm wood, 150mm×90mm.)
lines.text_raw: For the base, cut a piece 5 7/8"×3 5/8" (or for 8mm wood, 150mm×90mm.)

lines.text: For the lid, cut a piece 5½"×3¼" (or for 8mm wood, 140mm×82mm.)
lines.text_raw: For the lid, cut a piece 5½"×3¼" (or for 8mm wood, 140mm×82mm.)

lines.text: For the control panel, cut a piece 4¾"×2½" (or for 8mm wood, 124mm×65mm.)
lines.text_raw: For the control panel, cut a piece 4¾"×2½" (or for 8mm wood, 124mm×65mm.)

lines.text: Use sandpaper and a sanding block to put a small bevel around the top edges of the base and lid pieces.
lines.text_raw: Use sandpaper and a sanding block to put a small bevel around the top edges of the base and lid pieces.

lines.text: Using a sash clamp or band clamp, glue and clamp the pieces together into a box shape, with the end pieces abutting the sides. Let dry.
lines.text_raw: Using a sash clamp or band clamp, glue and clamp the pieces together into a box shape, with the end pieces abutting the sides. Let dry.

lines.text: Drill a hole in the bottom right rear corner of the enclosure for the audio jack. I used a 23/64" bit 20mm from the side and 8mm from the bottom, although anything in this general range will do. Countersink the hole slightly with a bigger drill bit.
lines.text_raw: Drill a hole in the bottom right rear corner of the enclosure for the audio jack. I used a 23/64" bit 20mm from the side and 8mm from the bottom, although anything in this general range will do. Countersink the hole slightly with a bigger drill bit.

lines.text: Using wood clamps, glue and clamp the sides of the case centered onto the base piece. Let dry.
lines.text_raw: Using wood clamps, glue and clamp the sides of the case centered onto the base piece. Let dry.

lines.text: Place the hinges on the lid about 3/8" (or 1cm) in from the side, mark the screw holes with a pencil, and drill 1/16" holes for the hinge screws.
lines.text_raw: Place the hinges on the lid about 3/8" (or 1cm) in from the side, mark the screw holes with a pencil, and drill 1/16" holes for the hinge screws.

lines.text: Screw the hinges to  the lid.
lines.text_raw: Screw the hinges to  the lid.

lines.text: With the lid in place, use a pencil to draw around the position of the hinges on the rear side piece.
lines.text_raw: With the lid in place, use a pencil to draw around the position of the hinges on the rear side piece.

lines.text: Use a small chisel to cut a recess into the wood in the shape of the hinges about 1/8" (3mm) deep.
lines.text_raw: Use a small chisel to cut a recess into the wood in the shape of the hinges about 1/8" (3mm) deep.

lines.text: Mark and drill 1/16" holes for the hinges in the recesses, and screw on the lid.
lines.text_raw: Mark and drill 1/16" holes for the hinges in the recesses, and screw on the lid.

lines.text: Using your completed circuit board as a template, drill the holes to fit in the control panel: ¼" for pots and LEDs, and 3/16" for the toggle switch. Also drill a 15/32" hole at lower left for the pushbutton.
lines.text_raw: Using your completed circuit board as a template, drill the holes to fit in the control panel: ¼" for pots and LEDs, and 3/16" for the toggle switch. Also drill a 15/32" hole at lower left for the pushbutton.

lines.text: Finish the wood by rubbing it with beeswax or polish. Now the box is ready for fitting the electronics.
lines.text_raw: Finish the wood by rubbing it with beeswax or polish. Now the box is ready for fitting the electronics.

lines.text: Fit the plastic LED holders to the front panel. To help the LEDs fit, I snipped the two longer holding clips off.
lines.text_raw: Fit the plastic LED holders to the front panel. To help the LEDs fit, I snipped the two longer holding clips off.

lines.text: Press the circuit board onto the back of the control panel, fitting all components through their holes.
lines.text_raw: Press the circuit board onto the back of the control panel, fitting all components through their holes.

lines.text: When the circuit board is in the right spot, tack the toggle switch to the wood with a little hot glue.
lines.text_raw: When the circuit board is in the right spot, tack the toggle switch to the wood with a little hot glue.

lines.text: Fit the pushbutton switch through its hole in the panel front. Bend its solder tabs back, and solder the push-button switch wires to the solder tabs. Add hot glue to hold the pushbutton in place.
lines.text_raw: Fit the pushbutton switch through its hole in the panel front. Bend its solder tabs back, and solder the push-button switch wires to the solder tabs. Add hot glue to hold the pushbutton in place.

lines.text: Fit the ¼" panel-mount audio jack to the case and hot-glue it in place.
lines.text_raw: Fit the ¼" panel-mount audio jack to the case and hot-glue it in place.

lines.text: Use hot glue to secure the audio jack programming port along the top edge of the  circuit board.
lines.text_raw: Use hot glue to secure the audio jack programming port along the top edge of the  circuit board.

lines.text: Clip a 9V battery onto the battery clip.
lines.text_raw: Clip a 9V battery onto the battery clip.

lines.text: Hold the battery under the right side of the control panel and fit the panel into the case.
lines.text_raw: Hold the battery under the right side of the control panel and fit the panel into the case.

lines.text: Screw the knobs onto the potentiometers with their included "grub screws" (set screws).
lines.text_raw: Screw the knobs onto the potentiometers with their included "grub screws" (set screws).

lines.text: Your hardware is now  completed.
lines.text_raw: Your hardware is now  completed.

lines.text: Download and install the free Picaxe Programming Editor Software from http://rev-ed.co.uk/picaxe, under the Software tab.
lines.text_raw: Download and install the free Picaxe Programming Editor Software from http://rev-ed.co.uk/picaxe, under the Software tab.

lines.text: Download the BASIC program file Luna_Mod.bas from http://makezine.com/26/lunamod.
lines.text_raw: Download the BASIC program file Luna_Mod.bas from http://makezine.com/26/lunamod.

lines.text: Lift up the control panel and connect the Picaxe programming cable between the Luna Mod programming port and your computer.
lines.text_raw: Lift up the control panel and connect the Picaxe programming cable between the Luna Mod programming port and your computer.

lines.text: Launch the Picaxe Programming Editor Software. Select File ⇒ Open, then select Luna_Mod.bas from the folder you downloaded it into.
lines.text_raw: Launch the Picaxe Programming Editor Software. Select '''File ⇒ Open''', then select ''Luna_Mod.bas'' from the folder you downloaded it into.

lines.text: With the Luna Mod connected to the computer, power it up using its on/off switch.
lines.text_raw: With the Luna Mod connected to the computer, power it up using its on/off switch.

lines.text: Press the computer’s F5 key to compile and load the Luna_Mod.bas program onto the Luna Mod. After the program has transferred, you should see a “Download was successful!” message box. Then disconnect the programming cable and refit the control panel.
lines.text_raw: Press the computer’s F5 key to compile and load the ''Luna_Mod.bas'' program onto the Luna Mod. After the program has transferred, you should see a “Download was successful!” message box. Then disconnect the programming cable and refit the control panel.

lines.text: Your Luna Mod is ready to play!
lines.text_raw: Your Luna Mod is ready to play!

lines.text: When you turn on the Luna Mod, the power light should come on, and the Tempo LED should flash.
lines.text_raw: When you turn on the Luna Mod, the power light should come on, and the Tempo LED should flash.

lines.text: Plug some headphones in and press the Write button — you should hear some noise.
lines.text_raw: Plug some headphones in and press the Write button — you should hear some noise.

lines.text: Turn the Sound knob while pressing the button, and the sound should change. Now move the Tempo knob — you should hear the loop getting faster and slower. If all that works, you’re good to go.
lines.text_raw: Turn the Sound knob while pressing the button, and the sound should change. Now move the Tempo knob — you should hear the loop getting faster and slower. If all that works, you’re good to go.

lines.text: Otherwise, check your wiring against the Luna Mod schematic diagram found at the beginning of this project.
lines.text_raw: Otherwise, check your wiring against the Luna Mod schematic diagram found at the beginning of this project.

steps.title: Playing the Mod Sounds of the Luna Mod

lines.text: Playing the Luna Mod is a matter of experimentation. Keep in mind that you can always create breaks in the sound by turning the Sound knob completely counterclockwise.
lines.text_raw: Playing the Luna Mod is a matter of experimentation. Keep in mind that you can always create breaks in the sound by turning the Sound knob completely counterclockwise.

lines.text: I had an enormous amount of fun learning how to play the Luna Mod because I’d never played an instrument like it before. I usually start with a basic rhythm that I set up by moving the Sound knob quickly clockwise while pressing the Write button. Then I add tones and blips by putting the Sound knob into various spots and quickly pressing the Write button once or twice. With this basic rhythm in place, you can let it repeat or keep adding and overwriting tones as desired.
lines.text_raw: I had an enormous amount of fun learning how to play the Luna Mod because I’d never played an instrument like it before. I usually start with a basic rhythm that I set up by moving the Sound knob quickly clockwise while pressing the Write button. Then I add tones and blips by putting the Sound knob into various spots and quickly pressing the Write button once or twice. With this basic rhythm in place, you can let it repeat or keep adding and overwriting tones as desired.

lines.text: Another trick for playing the device is to record a loop with the Tempo knob at its slowest speed, then increase the tempo for a fast, highly detailed loop.
lines.text_raw: Another trick for playing the device is to record a loop with the Tempo knob at its slowest speed, then increase the tempo for a fast, highly detailed loop.

lines.text: When I set up the Luna Mod for recording, I usually connect it directly to my mixer/recorder. For a more refined sound, I sometimes plug it into a reverb pedal, then a delay pedal, then the mixer/recorder.
lines.text_raw: When I set up the Luna Mod for recording, I usually connect it directly to my mixer/recorder. For a more refined sound, I sometimes plug it into a reverb pedal, then a delay pedal, then the mixer/recorder.

lines.text: The Luna Mod program only uses 81 of the 256 bytes available on the Picaxe 08M’s onboard memory. So with the Luna Mod’s built-in programming port, you have lots of room to modify and hack the software to make new sounds and functions.
lines.text_raw: The Luna Mod program only uses 81 of the 256 bytes available on the Picaxe 08M’s onboard memory. So with the Luna Mod’s built-in programming port, you have lots of room to modify and hack the software to make new sounds and functions.

lines.text: Enjoy, and let us know what you come up with!
lines.text_raw: Enjoy, and let us know what you come up with!

guide.summary: A simple handheld synth and looper box that generates intriguing sonic rhythms.
guide.title: The Luna Mod Looper

tools.notes: used to fit grub screws (set screws) on knobs
if needed to cut stripboard to size
for wood. Power saws can be used, but exercise caution because the pieces are small.
for listening to your new Luna Mod
for gluing together side and end pieces of box
Download "Luna_Mod_Schematic2.bmp" at http://makezine.com/26/lunamod. Updated as of 01/09/12.
